review_title: Work/Life balance actually is a priority at NU.
job_title: Senior Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros:
I've worked for NU for 5 years now, and I have to say that my time here has been nothing less than great. It's been so great, that my entire first year here after graduating was a bit of a culture-shock to me from leaving the part-time work force before where I held multiple part-time jobs. 

It's been a wonderful organization to be a part of where I've felt they actually do support their employees and foster an environment of continued upward growth while also understanding how there needs to be an established work/life balance.
cons: To be honest, I really haven't encountered many, if any at all. The location is beautiful, the hours are manageable. The only con I guess I have which isn't with NU itself is the commute. But even then NU has been accommodating since the pandemic in allowing workers to work from home. Even now after the apex of the pandemic and in it's decline, NU continues to be understanding of how most of our lives have changed and allow for a flexible work arrangement.

review_title: Great for Entry-Level Employees, Severely Lacking for Tenured Staff
pros: Good for entry-level employees looking for great benefits. They offer tuition benefits for full-time employees and have great health insurance, 403b retirement matching and 3 weeks of PTO and 15 sick days per year.
cons: They are always very short staffed and say they promote work/life balance but will run you into the ground first and offer little support. Use your PTO, use your benefits, don't wait for things to quiet down because they never will. 2-3% yearly raises, even COLA raises, are hard to come by over the last 3 years, even for tenured staff, because there isn't money. Be careful, anytime I've seen a new hire join in the last couple years, many departments will overload them with the work of 2-3 jobs to the point of burnout. Be clear on your scope of work if you can and know you may need to advocate for yourself.

review_title: Merit Increase? Cost of Living? Never Heard of them!
pros:
If you have a kid in high school and want to take advantage of the portable tuition benefit, your compensation is pretty close to market rates.

For other staffers, you'll work at a place where you'll be treated like a member of a lower caste and be paid 20% less than you'll get elsewhere.
cons:
So it is that time of the year again. The unwashed masses get a form letter to tell them that despite Northwestern giving themselves a healthy raise again this year (in the form of increased tuition), the staff that actually "works" will get a couple of percents thrown at them as a gesture of dismissal.

Hello - job market? Hello - cost of living?

Nope, don't care.

Meanwhile, the Dean's Office and faculty members formed a conga line a few months ago to get their share of "market adjustments" and "retention pay"

When asked, the administration denies this even goes on, but people talk and people leave documents out in the open...

review_title: Expect too much for too little
pros: Nice people, good insurance, pretty campus
cons:
The pay at Northwestern is terrible. They really like to push the idea that they have good benefits, and they do, the problem is that you have to work there for several years to get all of the benefits offered. They also have a problem with paying hourly employees for their full time worked. My department is full time at 37.5 hours. They will not pay for anything over 37.5, instead they want you to leave early another day if you worked overtime. This seems shady and possibly illegal to me.

They require 5 references. This is just ridiculous.

pros: Current employees have a 10% retirement match if they put in 5%. That part is great. You also can pursue a master's degree and the University will pay for 90% of the tuition (but you will be taxed for that contribution past ~$5,000 so your paychecks are smaller while you're enrolled).
cons: They don't increase salaries to keep pace with cost of living or inflation. You have to complete a burdensome performance review process just to get a 2%-3% "merit" increase. It has always felt absurd and now it seems downright silly. Employees have to pay to park on campus. That's right, you will pay to park at your workplace. They continue to be resistant and a little weird about remote work arrangements. It's obvious almost no one wants to be on campus 40 hours a week and most roles don't require it, but they're pressuring people to come back and it's negatively impacting morale. They are also hiring people at higher salaries right now due to the competitive job market and that is creating pay inequity for current employees.

review_title: Often an exploitative work environment. Proceed cautiously.
pros:
- Unbeatable health benefits
- Lengthy winter break
- You frequently have the opportunity to work flexible hours (depends on the PI)
cons:
- Employer illegally refuses to offer overtime pay for non-exempt workers (leading staff members to perform unpaid labor)
- Little ability to advance or receive compensation increases
- Intensely hierarchical environment
- Staff of color perform immense labor for (mostly white) faculty members with 0 recognition. You are lucky if the PI includes you in a footnote on manuscripts for studies for which you did the vast majority of the work. Often PIs do not even know much about the very studies they are supposedly leading (don't know the interview protocols, survey instruments, recruitment goals, timelines, etc.) and research coordinators are expected to be grateful to be saddled with all the work while making subpar compensation and receiving no institutional credit.

review_title: Prestigious and cognitively engaging, but low pay
pros:
-Good school name
-Great scientists
-I was allowed to have my own research directions (so long as still relevant to the lab) and was given the opportunity to lead a team on a project.
cons:
-Low pay unless you start getting into senior scientist positions; but that's the same for almost all academia positions
-No real amenities; e.g. you still have to pay for a gym membership
-General work-related requirements aren't covered; e.g. you have to pay for a university ID card, pay for the train/travel (unless you are conveniently on the bus route), etc.
-No bonuses or any extra stuff involving compensation
-The university "offers" benefits like healthcare, but you still pay the university to pay the insurance companies (i.e. you get Northwestern University as a middle-man).

All in all, subtract about $5k from your paygrade to cover transit, healthcare, etc. 

There's a reason I've left...make sure you *know* your pay.

pros: As a postdoc, you hear horror stories on forums about the lack of support and insufficient training opportunities. That was not my experience at Northwestern. Within my individual work unit/department, I had a lot of opportunity to co-design my postodoctoral training plan. My advisor had me using the NIH professional development plan template to start my training. We co-created professional development goals and reflected on my progress using this template. It was very helpful for my growth. In addition, even though I was in a smaller department, I was very integrated into the overall postdoc system. I got to meet other postdocs and faculty from departments outside of my own and even presented research at a Northwestern sponsored colloquium. I was introduced to the postdoctoral networking group very on and attending social functions through this group. This was important for my social and professional life. I also got to present at multiple conferences due to the funding. Finally, I was able to grow my teaching experience by guest lecturing and participating in Northwestern's Center for Integrated Teaching and Learning Program.
cons: The location is pretty remote with respect to the downtown of Chicago. It is very expensive to live in Evanston and housing options are scant. I didn't get any resources from Northwestern ahead of time to help me re-locate. I also feel like the financial onboarding was haphazard. There were a couple of unecessary trips back and forth to the human resources office to set up my W2 and I almost did'nt get paid my first check because they misplaced the certification support docs for my completion of the PHD/Dissertation.

job_title: Research Study Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent reputation. Great benefits for both exempt and non-exempt roles. Friendly colleagues. Fairly easy commute (downtown Chicago campus). Lots of networking opportunities.
cons:
This is one of those workplaces where if you are a 'rockstar' hardworking employee you will be rewarded with more work -- not a raise or promotion. 

No clear paths or structure to earn a promotion, or salary increase. If you manage to get hired, negotiate for the highest base salary you can FROM THE START. It's likely the only time the conversation will happen over the next 5 years. 

It is also easier to quit your current position and re-apply for a different, higher paying job at NU than it is to get promoted for being a good employee. If you manage to negotiate a raise, it will be marginal (less than 5%).

Your experience will vary wildly based on the PI or the department you are in. Some PIs will be very involved with the day-to-day operations, while others you may not speak to more than once a week. 

Admin assistants are stretched way too thin, so others need to pick up the slack/overflow work as a result. This is not the admins fault -- they are just understaffed.

Probably unsurprising, but every PhD and MD thinks they are the smartest person at the university. Always stay mindful of egos when addressing anyone or the condescension will rain down.

review_title: Alumni Relations and Development - Bureaucratic, Reactionary and Archaic
pros: Pride in working in an environment where great things are achieved and interesting people are involved. Access to decent benefits.
cons: Archaic management styles and working arrangements. No ability to rate, grade or review your supervisor(s) or offer them any kind of feedback in a formal way. Divisive, reactive culture with ongoing issues between different functional areas of the department and constant last-minute planning/execution. Non-traditional work arrangements are rare and frowned upon even though this is touted as a major benefit of working at NU. Very uneven organizational structure with little opportunity for advancement. No focus on hiring from within and developing internal talent. Interview process is too long, drawn out and does not allow for candidates to do more than answer the same outdated questions multiple times and to different groups of people. Distant, unapproachable HR and recruiting team. Very little incentive to perform well aside from fear of poor performance evaluation ratings and reduction in annual pay-increase which is already laughably low. Long-term planning does not involve lower-level staff who are ultimately affected most by departmental change. This is not a fun or rewarding job. I feel that I have to conform to outdated standards in order to fit in and receive no appreciation for my work.

review_title: Great benefits, competitive salary, good staff - discounting the dinosaurs.
pros: The benefits at NU are very good - the retirement is basically a double match 403B, which is ridiculous, especially compared to the private sector.  The salary scale in IT is a little squished - higher at the bottom, lower at the top - than you'd see going private.  The work environment is relaxed and job security is almost locked in after a year.  This is both good and bad, as I'll get to below.  The staff is diverse and has a broad, non-traditional background.  English majors could be server guys if they have the skills, which makes for a fun group of people to work with.
cons:
Advancement at NU is hit or miss.  Because it's easygoing and stable, and because they are so  averse to firing, people tend to hunker down and stay... forever.  If you're satisfied where you are, that's awesome.  If you're looking to move up, the path can be a little cloudy.  You have to be willing to move from one department to the next, which can be a total crapshoot as to what you're walking into.  Also, there's a lot of walking dead around here - people with no hope of advancement and no respect from their managers, who just kind of persist.

Finally, the raises are paltry to say the least.  The excuse is always "We're a non-profit!"  Yes.  A non-profit with a twelve billion dollar endowment that charges 50k per year to its students.  So know that, so long as you stay in one job, your salary will struggle to keep up with inflation.

cons: Insurance options are terrible and expensive. Nothing really amazing about other benefits, except the tuition reimbursement program. The non-NU supervisor has no familiarity with benefits or employee rights, therefore making staff feel as though there is no advocacy in place when dealing with harassment or other work related issues/concerns. Overall, good people, great location by the lake in Chicago, okay working environment, but very low pay and stagnant career progression opportunities.

review_title: Northwestern great for benefits, despite incompetent and unhelpful HR
pros: Benefits including health insurance, tuition assistance and 403b retirement matching is great.
cons: Human Resources is very corrupt and unhelpful.  When faced with a problem with your manager, HR often takes the side of the management and offers little assistance or advice, even to a seasoned employee with an exemplary work record.  They cover up and turn a blind eye to up openly problematic management and personnel issues in departments and suggest subordinates look elsewhere when faced with challenges.  They offer no helpful or beneficial support, even when a manager has repeatedly been warned and reported for inappropriate behavior.  More specifically, a manager was praying aloud in the office and discussing religion (in addition to many other management infractions...poor work competency, mental health issues, poor management skills, etc) and this information was reported to HR on several occasions and they turned a blind eye to it.  Several people reported the incidences and nothing was done to assist the subordinates who were subjected to the behavior.  Praying and discussing religion should be a RED FLAG to any Human Resources department, but NU HR did absolutely nothing, even when senior management (who this manager reported to) went directly to HR to report the behavior.  Unacceptable and very disappointing to know that your rights are not protected by Human Resources.

review_title: Good employer with good benefits, lower pay than you might expect
pros: Great benefits, excellent university, good opportunities to advance your career in academia, and challenging, high-quality research environment. You are surrounded by some of the top minds doing interesting work on a truly endless range of subjects. A great place to be if you like to stay up-to-date on academic trends - my experience with researchers here is that they work very hard to get ahead.  Evanston is a nice city, and you can enjoy some good outdoor spaces during breaks. My experience is that people in general are friendly and helpful in cross-departmental interactions.  Also, there are good opportunities to move within the university after 1 year of service.
cons: Low pay, mid- to upper-level management are not always competent, slow-moving administrative processes (like all universities, or so I've heard), high expectations with little reward or incentive.  Because it is a Research 1 institution, the pace can be high-pressure at times.  In my experience, staff are often not always recognized often for their good work.  Negotiations about employment have been less than stellar, and some HR processes involve lists of seemingly endless forms for small changes (probably not unique to NU!)  The location is nice, but you are slightly out of Evanston, so it's not always convenient if you don't drive.

review_title: I'm happy to be employed but wish my talents were more appreciated.
pros: The longer you work here, the harder it is to get fired.  The tuition reimbursement is really good for your children.  This is most beneficial if you are faculty, since you are probably done with pursuing higher education.  The work life balance is fair.  If you have a decent supervisor, they will usually give you the time off that is needed.  If you are a salaried employee, you get tons of sick days.  I believe it's over 100 a year.  These days will of course correspond to your short and long term disability.  You must pay a monthly fee for these benefits, but it is quite small.
cons: The salaries for a majority of the jobs are really bad.  Longevity in the company is not appreciated at all.  Employess are not given that much of a tuition discount at this university.  Employees are not given any discounts at other schools.  This is a real bummer because this university does not have a wide range of degrees to get.  The career opportunities are quite limited.  If you start off as a data person, you will most likely be forced to continue in this line of work because each time you try to transfer to a different job, they want experience.

job_title: Web Content Specialist in Evanston, IL
pros:
Please note: This review is specific to my experience at the McCormick School of Engineering. Jobs at Northwestern vary considerably because the school contains a huge number of entities, each with their own reporting structure.

That said: Northwestern is a wonderful place to work. Beautiful campus, talented and smart people, and what seemed to be above-average compensation. I worked with one of the best teams I've ever worked with, led by probably the best manager I've ever worked for, and it was a pleasure. 

Benefits are very good overall as well. Ideal for someone who'll soon have a kid in college as well — they do a tuition exchange program that can knock thousands off your dependent child's bill, even if he or she doesn't go to Northwestern.
cons:
If you live in Chicago, depending on where you're located it can be kind of a long commute if you're using the CTA. Driving is actually a better way to get there if you're in north-central to north Chicago anywhere near Lake Shore.

Also: For a time I was a half-time employee, and during this time the school charged me twice the rate for my health benefits that I would've been paying as a full-time employee. In other words: Half the pay, twice the health costs. This caused me a lot of problems financially.

review_title: Has changed for the worse! Ratings are skewed by research staff :(
job_title: Program Assistant III in Evanston, IL
pros: The only good thing are the benefits. Affordable insurance, tuition assistance, and the retirement plan can't be beat.
cons:
Northwestern has grown worse for the wear in the time I was there.  Aggressive, bloated and top heavy management insists on micromanaging to unreasonable levels.  Speaking out against it will do you no good as you receive ZERO support from HR even in cases where a manager has blatantly harassed an employee.  Furthermore, expect to be blackballed off the record, so that it makes it impossible for you to go anywhere else but out the door.

Also, raises are non-existent and it doesn't matter how hard you try.  Favoritism is quite apparent.  Additionally, many positions have been downgraded and most program assistant job openings are temporary so they can avoid paying out benefits for as long as possible.  If you're permanent and want to promote up to the next program level, but it's a temp position? Yeah, you guessed it.  You have to quit and become a temp.  So much for maintaining your service to the organization.

pros: Being a professor gives you significant time flexibility. Also, you can work at problems that really interest you. The continuous interaction with students and the teaching help keep you sharp, and you constantly learn new things as your own domain evolves. These things are true about the profession in general, and Northwestern is really good at honoring them. The Dean is great and helps promote the school and its faculty.
cons: The pay is lower than what you can get in industry for the same time involvement and effort. There are politics at every workplace, and Northwestern is not immune to them, but overall they are not affecting most professors much. There is a lack of effort from the administration to realize policies that would greatly help their employees personal and professional life (e.g., most respectable universities have childcare facilities on campus, but Northwestern has repeatedly rejected proposals to establish one, although there is great demand for it). There is a lot of red tape (maybe more than most places) and micromanagement of finances, which unnecessarily complicates things. Some entities do not seem to offer anything to the organization but they consume financial resources, and I wonder why they still exist (e.g., TGS).

pros: I have met lots of great people and began to network.
cons: They usually give the bare minimum increase even though according to their own HR guide people in a position like myself are usually doing things  that a manager or higher technician should do.  Instead of bumping people up they come up with reasons or just force you to take on the responsibility without any form of increased  compensation for the increased workload.  Or in my case they begin to ignore the issue all together.   They don't offer overtime on most occasions and instead favor compensation time.  This policy also has a lot of gray areas favoring the employer (if you don't take it within a week its gone and if you have to come in on a Saturday most times you are out of luck and end up working for free) this policy does vary between departments however, I have heard similar complaints from people in different departments than my own.

pros: good academics (classes and teaching)

job_title: Program Assistant IV in Evanston, IL
pros: Great health care, retirement, and tuition benefits.  In a well run department it can be a very vibrant and fulfilling place to work.  Can also be a wonderful opportunity to learn about cutting edge research.
cons:
Working at NU often feels like a caste system to me, and the faculty are in the cloud hovering over the pyramid of administrative deans, senior management, middle management, and administrative staff.  A hierarchy is evident in most all corporate employment structures, though the separation between faculty and staff is more apparent than I ever experienced working in corporations.

This is unfortunate because a large portion university activities happen because of the work being done by those at the bottom of the hierarchy. 

Because university staff positions do offer a number of great benefits, and this should not to be overlooked or minimized, even entry level positions have many applicants.  This allows the university to ignore what I believe is a pretty significant employee morale issue. A dysfunctional department will still be able to easily attract new staff, and many employees will remain in dysfunctional departments just to hold onto a great healthcare package.

pros:
- Great benefits
- Great location

cons: **This is for the Chicago campus, specifically the medical school** University administration treats the staff like garbage. HR is a joke and never has any idea what is going on, and will never advocate for employees. Instead they take the side of the administration 99/100 times, and every person in HR you talk to will give you a different answer to the same question, and treat you like you're crazy when you tell them someone else in their department gave you a different answer. Salaries are nowhere near comparable to the private sector, despite being a $2 billion/year research enterprise, and while there are faculty making as much as $2 million/year, staff do not receive any kind of bonus when we help a PI bring in an important grant (faculty regularly get bonuses, staff bonuses were recently eliminated altogether). There is no internal loyalty, they will almost always pay an external hire $10-20,000 more than they would if they were to promote an internal hire, and make no effort to make compensation equitable when this happens. Don't waste your career here.

review_title: Collaboration encouraged but intellectual silos hinder growth
pros: Great benefits and learning opportunities. Many food options are the Chicago campus. NU parking is phenomenal and affordable. Being part of cutting edge research is exciting. The work atmosphere is less intense than other ivy league institutions. In group settings, being able to speak your mind is encouraged. Advice is given constructively and not in an condescending manner. The diversity of the staff gives the organization a wide variety of ideas coming from all parts of the world.
cons: Room for job growth is extremely difficult because well defined career ladders do not exist for middle management. The focus of career development is mainly top heavy. Trying to collaborate across multiple disciplines on large projects take a long time because it's hard to agree and decided on an action plan on regulatory and legal roadblocks to all stakeholders. The NU culture is very decentralized and this lack of institutional cohesiveness hinders innovative research keeping up to speed with other nationally acclaimed initiatives.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

cons: None that I can think of

pros: Great organization to work for.
cons: There are no cons great place

review_title: A decent place to work with completely incompetent management
pros: Good benefits, generous vacation and sick time, good retirement benefits. During an economic recession, an educational institution is a good place to be as layoffs are kept to a minimum.
cons: Management is completely incompetent. I have never seen so many do so little yet position themselves to look so well in the eyes of their superiors. Oh, and if you work here, sharpen your butt-kissing skills, because the only way to get advancement is to make very nice with the people on top. If you do advance, prepare to spend the remainder of your professional life in debilitating anxiety over whether your dean approves of the job you're doing.

pros: Good pay and a friendly environment
cons: Toxic leadership and worrisome policies

review_title: Terrible Senior Leadership, No Advancement Opportunities
pros: The benefits and pay are good for the amount of work expected--which is not a lot during slower times in the year. Most staff is collaborative and interested in improving the student experience. Depending on your supervisor and department, it can be a great place to just bide your time and gain skills.
cons: No real room for promotions or movement within departments--it's impossible to get new jobs created/approved, which is especially unfortunate for those who have put in a few years and are looking to expand their responsibilities and pay. Some students are great but administrators coddle many students and create unreasonable expectations about the level of support that will be provided. Many members of senior leadership have very difficult personalities. I was extremely unlucky to have the supervisor I had. It colored my entire experience and made it impossible to stay in the position. Other support staff have different experiences and it really depends on the directors/senior leadership that you're working with. The responsibilities and expectations are not unreasonable but navigating the politics and personalities is tiring and emotionally draining.

pros: Nice campus, but you will not have time to enjoy it if you worked under a micro-manager like I did.
cons:
I worked at a research lab call EIRG at the School of Communication. It was the worst experience that I've ever had in my 10 years work life. 
Here are some examples of the micromanagement, to list but a few. 
Everyone must report their detailed time use IN WRITTEN every week. 
The supervisor asked us to cc her EVERY SINGLE emails that we send. You are required to reply to every email that you received. Yes, this includes emails that are not really relevant to you, but somehow you are cc'd on. 
Emails should use bullets to list items or questions. 
Everyone is REQUIRED to take a 30 min lunch break, but CANNOT be longer than 30 min. If your lunch break is longer than that, you have to email supervisor in advance for a written permission. 
They do performance review EVERY QUARTER, while the University's requirement is once every year. They frequently threaten you to put you on a Performance Improvement Plan, but they never really do.
Everyone is required to lock their computers at the end of every work day. But your lab space has no locking drawers,  and you will be blamed for leaving your computed unlocked. 
......

pros: Most of the faculty and staff are some of the best people I have ever met and are experts in their fields.  I would work with these people again and again.
cons: Salary is typically 10-20K less than the same position at other companies and positions within Northwestern University as all the money goes towards Apple products and some over priced faculty.  Also, leadership does not listen to IT in the least, no matter the direction (square peg, round hole) leadership will be so narrow minded and soft focused on the bigger picture they could not see a hazard if it popped up in front of them and said boo.  Management of the technology staff is about as spineless and gutless as a jelly fish.  Stating they back up the team.. but when push comes to shove they hide with their tails under the table protecting their own 110+ K pr yr salary (I saw an excel file couple of years ago)

pros: Benefits are outstanding.  They have a retirement match up to 5% and put in an additional 5%.  Health insurance is affordable.
cons: The pay is terrible and there has been lots of downsizing and job reclassification in recent years. You will work the job of two people. Huge culture shift from years ago is tacking place in that it's taking on a more "corporate" feel in a lot of areas.  I think there are many unhappy staff and this is not reflected in the overall rating because the reviews are affected by graduate students.  Management does not have concern for workers well being and will run off even long time employees if you do not conform to their current paradigm.  The turn over is way too high and it's hard to make meaningful connections with others. Career growth is based on who you know, not what you know.  No accountability for upper management and how they treat others.

review_title: Good research environment and beautiful lakeside view, however  not the best salary/working conditions for grad students
job_title: Visiting Predoctoral Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros:
It is a great research university. There is an emphasis to develop high-impact leading and innovative research. Colleagues are in general eager to discuss new projects or share their insights into one's research. Work ethic is in general very good.
The university constantly attracts first-class speakers to give lectures in seminars or scientific conferences.
The Science Library is not the most complete I've ever been to but still has many relevant titles and great electronic resources.
cons:
Massive buildings like the Tech Institute or Francis Searle are not the most welcoming inside. Some of the grad student offices can be dark with few or no windows, with old furniture and crowded which is not an optimal working environment.
The same goes for the central library. The working experience could be better but the overal design does not help.
There is also not a lot of communication between departments around joint projects.

review_title: Times will get worse before they get better
pros:
The reputation of Northwestern University is strong and has often attracted the best talent.
403b match for benefits of 10% for 5% of your contribution is fairly high.
Tuition discounts and additional access to education opportunities.
Beautiful campus as well as many buildings on campus.
cons:
Recent financial crisis has hampered the progress of the university as a whole, whether that would be in regards to financial growth, employee retention or quality of education. Projections are for this crisis to continue at least until 2021.
Due to this crisis, management mainly focuses on short-term cost savings and in many cases disregards the long-term overall goals. An example of this is the rarely high turnover in our department with no interest on the management's end to retain high quality talent.
Non-competitive pay.

pros: nothing to say about it
cons: limit space to get promoted

review_title: The pros and cons of working at Northwestern University
pros: Very friendly coworkers. Beautiful campus. If you are into performance metrics, this is the place for you. Pays better than fast food restaurants.
cons: Although they do pay better than fast food restaurants, it's hard to make ends meet with the salary they give pay you. It started out as a very friendly place to work, great coworkers, and we had wonderful management. Lately they have drastically changed their management style. Everything is now performance metrics. Coworkers are afraid to talk to one another or take time off. I've heard from people that they have been restructuring and laying of or "retiring" loyal workers who have work there for years.

review_title: Great place to learn, not for the a
pros: Tuition reimbursement on undergrad classes - you will pay more for books than you will for undergrad classes.  Access to brilliant faculty and students.  Beautiful setting.  6+years and you get tuition benefits for your kids.  Good insurance and retirement contributions.  Access to tremendous university resources.  Many departments have laidback atmosphere, relaxed dress code, flex hours are common.
cons: Bureaucratic.  No incentive pay.  1-2% annual merit pay increase.  Performance evaluations are a joke.  Inadequate tuition support for Kellogg classes.  Employees hired from outside can negotiate 2x as much as those promoted from within - you can't negotiate salary if promoted from within - you automatically get the lowest level in the new pay grade.  So there's next to zero career tracking/mentoring for non-research positions and very little incentive for advancement.

review_title: If you can deal with the quirks of a large bureaucracy, Northwestern is an excellent place to work.
pros: Northwestern creates a very nurturing environment for its employees, promoting personal and professional growth.  It is a high performing organization across many disciplines and there are many opportunities for academics and non-academics alike.  The benefits cannot be beat, and work-life balance is outstanding.  I never took work home. There are variations from department to department, but in general, I think the culture is excellent and NU is a great organization of which to be a part.
cons: NU is a large, long-established bureaucracy, and with that come the attributes often associated with the inner workings of a large, long-established bureaucracy (e.g. slowness, very hierarchical top-down governance, etc.)  Also, while there are many job opportunities, it can be a little tough to move-up for mid-career employees because many people in the mid-range stay at those jobs for long periods of time.  As such, not as many openings exist for those with 7-8+ years of experience as for entry level employees / employees with only a couple years of experience.

pros:
Diverse, accepting, intellectually vibrant community.  Wonderful students. Educational events on campus.
Employees are encouraged to express individuality. 
Morty does a lot to encourage & celebrate community. 
Up-to-date technology
Employee ducational discount is good - except for MBA. Unfortunately continuing ed classes are not the same quality & rigor as full-time.  
Good family & medical leave policies
Convenient to transit.
cons:
Pay for professionals is low:  <$30k for Assistant. $40k for manager; $50k for Assistant Director.  Annual raises are 1% or less.  No bonus/merit pay.    
Little room for progression for professionals (marketing/admissions/IT/finance/ops/etc.).  If you do progress, the pay for someone who moves up is much lower than someone coming new from the outside.  
Poor employee morale.
Poor metrics for measuring results on new initiatives.  
Some faculty are difficult to work with: treat all non-faculty like secretaries.  
HR is bureaucratic and difficult to navigate.  
Limited parking on campus.

job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: This is a wealthy, well-funded university that in my experience will help you find the resources to perform whatever types of engineering research you are interested in. Since my department is small, there isn't a ton of competition amongst other students to get the advisor you want or the projects that you want to work on. After going to a large public university for undergrad, this has been a much better experience in that respect. My schedule is completely flexible and the expectations for hours worked (40-50 per week) is very reasonable and allows a good work/life balance. However, this absolutely depends on what department you are in and who your PI is, so I think I have gotten pretty lucky and wouldn’t guarantee this to be the case.
cons: Evanston is not the most happening college town - I live in Chicago and have to commute in (over half an hour driving) because I don't think I'd feel fulfilled in other aspects of my life living near campus, which is basically in a quiet suburb full of undergrads and families.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Chicago, IL
pros:
-good place to work if your exit field wants to see a certain tier of school on your resume
-better funding than most lower level schools, but not perfect
cons: If you are a minority being recruited as part of a D&I initiative, beware. Do not expect to be seen or heard by leadership once they get you in the door. Understand that every lab runs like an individual business, so if you end up in a lab that violates your rights as an employee, you will be largely on your own to deal with that. Expect to actively fight against being worked to death and fight for your right to work from home during a pandemic. Don’t expect any sensitivity or understanding of social issues and how that may impact your work life. Understand that like everything else, you will be on your own to handle that. Wipe your tears between meetings and get back to work. If this is worth the opportunities on the other side for you, I understand. Just know what you’re getting yourself into.

review_title: A supportive environment for graduate students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Locally, Northwestern has an excellent reputation.  The name carries a lot of prestige.  As a graduate student, you have access to a lot of benefits, like a u-pass (discounted pass for unlimited CTA travel), gym membership, access to excellent health facilities (including counseling) and a variety of student organizations and activities (although I haven't participated in very many besides intramural sports).  The graduate school has an office of fellowships to help students secure outside funding.  The graduate school also has (limited) travel funds available to students.  Individual departments often have separate travel grants as well.  Evanston borders Chicago, so there is plenty to do outside of academics.
cons: Departmental logistics can sometimes be slow and inefficient.  I've had payroll issues (e.g. erroneously receiving only a fraction of my paycheck) three times in 5 years.  Reimbursements are painfully slow, but at least they are an option (as opposed to paying out of pocket for all expenses).  Financial support for travel varies greatly across labs and departments.

review_title: Flexible job, great benefits, but low appreciation and little job growth
job_title: Project Coordinator I in Chicago, IL
pros: There is a great work/life balance with flexible hours and the benefits are great.  85% off undergrad classes for employees and weeks of sick and vacation time each year.
cons: There is little opportunity for growth unless you obtain a PhD and transition to faculty position in my department and raises are rarely more than cost of living increases despite consistent strong performance reviews.  Senior leadership lacks mentoring capabilities for both faculty and staff and there is no SOP training for new employees.  When staff have questions they are told to ask around until they find another coordinator who has been through the situation.  There is a general lack of communication between departments in the university as well.

job_title: Administrative Assistant IV in Evanston, IL
pros: Benefits, educational assistance and time off
cons: Don't get me started. Two things: misery and management. No way of moving up, at all, unless you are a great butt kisser. Program and Administrative Assistants are stuck in their positions for many years to come. You can be the employee of the year, it won't matter, trust me. Another thing of the past, performance reviews. They tend to demoralize and demotivate employees. High turnover in some positions lead to incompetent managers, trying to load you up with more tasks and work, all this while micromanaging. In all those years I have worked, I cannot say I really liked the place much. Get your degree and if you cannot get a promotion move to another school. Place that will actually appreciate you. Office politics are awful, lots of butt kissing. And holier- than- thou clueless managers.

review_title: One of the best jobs I've had
pros: In my current position, I am able to work remotely from home, have amazing time-off and medical benefits, super friendly staff, great people at the tops of their fields.  They also have a wildcard which gets you discounts at many local stores, restaurants, and retail stores (J. Crew, car rental places).  It's like having student discounts once again!
cons: In my current position, there isn't a clear path to progress upwards.  There is also a lot of disorganization, which I feel is pretty consistent in higher education.  It's just unfortunate that a Top 10 school is still so unorganized.

review_title: Poorly organized, no room for advancement
pros: Stable, decent benefits, hard to get fired unless you really screw up repeatly
cons: Management very unorganized. Ineffective planning, poor communication to staff about major changes. IT department in complete disarray. Low morale. Uncompetitive salary. No room for advancement. No appreciation for going above and beyond job description. No room for advancement, regardless of education or institutional knowledge.

review_title: Diverse culture, good benefits, uninspiring pay and growth
job_title: Research Technologist II in Evanston, IL
pros: For those interested in stability and an overall good working environment (with great benefits) then Northwestern is highly recommended. You have an opportunity to work with some of the most intelligent people involved in cutting edge research.  Northwestern also has a pretty good work /life balance but this will depend on your manager.
cons: I would not recommend Northwestern for those interested in rapid career growth - Northwestern holds an old-school style of seniority.  As with most large universities, Northwestern suffers from a siloed culture; your experience can very from department.  Pay increases also appear to be very standard (2-3%) and do not seem very dependent on performance evaluations.  There is often no clear pathway for advancement withing the university other than to move departments or schools.

review_title: Work there if you can afford to...
job_title: Program Assistant II in Evanston, IL
pros: The benefits packages are nice.  They have matching retirement and throw in 5% on top of that.   Reduced tuition is also a plus.  Most staff members are nice and welcoming (please don't be put off by a few bad apples).
cons: The pay, the pay, the pay.  Good lord is it bad.  As a Program Assistant II, my salary works out to $16.35/hr.  Take out deductions, taxes, etc. and there's not much more to life off of.  The other downside is that some of the faculty can be condescending toward staff by talking down to them, having a fit when something cannot be fixed easily (or at all for that matter) and general disrespect (some of the men are a bit sexist).

pros: I was taken way out of my comfort zone.  I'm sure most people are during their first undergraduate experience, but I gained a lot of insight dealing with people who are nothing like the people from my hometown.  Administration is very accessible and willing to help a student in need.  The environment can encourage you to stick up for yourself and become strong-minded.  Employers/recruiters are usually excited to speak to a Northwestern student with a high GPA.  The name Northwestern definitely gets recognized when job searching.
cons: Work-life balance is nonexistent.  In order to do really well academically, I'm pretty sure most people deprive themselves of a little sanity and a lot of sleep.  It has been my experience that students preach tolerance but do not practice it behind closed doors.

pros: Northwestern has a very bright undergraduate and graduate population, and the faculty are very involved in their research careers, providing a fantastic academic research environment.  The campuses in Evanston and Chicago provide a nice contrast and multiple options for the types of lifestyle someone might want.
cons: As a graduate student, the general benefits and salary are fairly competitive with lower tier universities, but somewhat lacking behind the universities Northwestern would like to compare itself to. Overall, while much of the research being conducted is top-tier, there is still a general conservative air about the administration that might inhibit more daring research to be conducted.

pros:
Beautiful campus to work on,  a lot community 
policing programs that allow you to get to know the students and faculty. There are opportunities to receive additional training
cons:
This department is so short staffed and officers 
of the least seniority are constantly being forced into overtime with no respect for quality life/work balance. Despite being short staffed there are certain officers that are given off prime days (i.e. fri & sat) for religious reasons forcing other officers into overtime.

pros: Flexibility. I have small children and a spouse with a chronic illness and the ability to be close to home and sometimes work from home has been a godsend.
cons: Payscale and PTO.  I took a 60% paycut to come here because I needed to be close to home.  We coasted on savings for a few years to bridge the gaps, but now we are living paycheck to paycheck.   For a family of four with one income, my take home pay is only $5k above the poverty line.  As or PTO, these is a huge gap in time for vacation eligibility.  Years 1-9 is 3 weeks per year and 9-19 is 4 weeks per year.   I think that first window should be shortened to reflect most current organizations  that add 4 weeks after five years.

review_title: Once upon a time, I thought it was the place to be... Now, I'm just frustrated.
pros:
Three weeks of vacation, plus additional week off over winter holiday.
Three weeks of sick time.
Retirement Employer Matching.
Portable Dependent Tuition Benefits
cons:
Non-existent leadership.
No accountability.
Lethargic, toxic workforce.
No room for advancement.

review_title: Northwestern provides a very good working environment and great benefits (as far as I know). Beware of the cold though!
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Chicago, IL
pros:
If you work and live in the downtown Chicago campus you cannot have a better location during the summer. You are in the center of the city with plenty of amenities and the lake front is just next door. If you are an foreign postdoc the international office is quite active (not that I have much to compare to though) and there are plenty of opportunities to meet new people and do fun activities.
The winter however, is long and cold. But I guess it is similar to other cities like Boston or New York.
I would say Northwestern has a very collaborative mindset but of course your specific work environment will depend upon the group you go work with.
cons: The stupidly long and freezing cold winter of Chicago

review_title: Amazing resources, beautiful campus, though a fragmented NU community makes for a wide array of experiences.
pros: unlimited resources - academic contacts, worldclass libraries, great discount on courses (75% off graduate courses, 85% for undergraduate), evanston is also a beautiful campus, right on the lake.  it all depends who you work for and who you work with, as the northwestern community is really divided - there's a lot of really exciting work going on that is often really fragmented - competition between departments and offices is common, so coordination is often a problem.   there are some ego issues.  if you're dealing with students, most of them are really bright and interesting, but can often be demanding and bratty as well.
cons: lack of coordination between departments and offices - a lot of interesting research and programs going on, but often a sense of competitiveness, sometimes smarmy people to work with.

review_title: Cutting edge in a few places, ridiculously archaic in most others
job_title: Current Staff Employee in Evanston, IL
pros:
- GREAT benefits. The 401K match is crazy good. Vacation is ample. 
- Very flexible, if your boss is flexible. All depends on the position. 
- Cutting edge in some places (use of virtualization), ridiculous use of open source or nothing at all in other areas
- Very good work/life balance
- Stable, very few layoffs
cons:
- If you don't land in the few good positions that will offer career advancement and/or skills enhancement that you can actually use on the job (vs just taking a class to check a box), watch out. 
- Negotiate hard on the starting salary or you will never get anywhere. Raises are not up to industry standards and promotion almost requires you to go into management
- Politics for the sake of politics, and over stuff that does not matter.

review_title: A great place to be complacent and stop doing research.
pros: Tenure, 10% match to 5% retirement contribution.
cons: Merit raises are regularly half the rate of inflation no matter what kind of year you have.  The only exception to this seems to be when you get another offer from a peer institution.  There is no faculty governance.

review_title: rewarding experience and high growth potential
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros:
Great education, lots of opportunities to grow. As a PhD student, I have worked in multiple labs, interned in different industries, and even got a management certificate from the Kellogg School of Business, for free. 

Strong brand. Northwestern is not only well recognized in the Midwest but also on both coasts (a little surprising to me). My roommate and I got jobs in the silicon valley and some classmates got jobs in NY, PA etc. Due to NU's reputation in the business world, some of my friends with PhD in engineering were offered jobs from MCK, BCG, and Bain.

Lots of fun! Evanston is a great suburb, only 30hr driving from downtown Chicago. Countless concerts in the summer. Always have trouble in deciding which one to go to. I am a big fan of NBA and it was great experience to witness the revival of the Bulls.
cons: Winter is a pain in the "windy city"

review_title: Disappointed in the true character of my employer.
pros: One of the best reasons to work for Northwestern University would be tuition reimbursement.  The institution offers 85% reimbursement for undergraduate programs and 75% for graduate. If advancement opportunities require an advanced degree, Northwestern would be a place I would personally recommend. Generous benefits package as well as vacation time also factor into the "best reasons" equation.
cons: On the outside looking in, Northwestern seemingly abounds with opportunity and appears  well-intentioned in terms of promotional and compensatory fairness.  However, if you look at the make-up of its senior management, administrators and supervisors, a different story emerges related to race.  Again, the make-up doesn't appear to be intentional, but I have seen many qualified African-Americans passed over for promotion and many unqualified or inexperienced people hired in their place.  Higher learning doesn't necessarily equate with a higher sense of fairness.

review_title: Solid benefits but you won't ever be a priority or given opportunities for growth
pros: Staff benefits are phenomenal: matching contributions to your 403b, health/dental/ vision insurance, lots of time off, AND tuition discounts for yourself and your family members. It's also great to work at a mission-driven place with smart people!
cons: Most positions have no clear path forward and, even if they do, getting promoted internally (meaning, within your particular department) is rare and difficult.  The pay is also far below the industry standard while the expectations for how much you're supposed to accomplish and your credentials for an open position are incredibly high.

review_title: The Good and Bad of NU
pros: The benefits are great (403b contribution/match, insurance rates, time off, etc.), and being a large institution there is room to advance and move up if you are willing to regularly change departments. There are a lot of smart people at NU.
cons: The department you are in determines everything. Some departments are stifling and traditional, with very rigid hours and demands that do now allow for reasonable work-life balance. Other departments are more laid back (especially in Evanston). The medical school is very, very political. It is not about productivity, doing good work or making PIs happy, it's about how well you play the game. It can be infuriating. Even those who are clearly incompetent at their jobs are given no recourse.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Note - being a graduate student is very professor dependent.  Personally I have a laid back professor who let's me pursue my passions here at Northwestern.  Weekly group meetings occur where each student in the lab presents on their progress from the previous week - expectations are reasonable.
cons: Graduation Politics: Aiming to graduate early can be a challenge - it is not in the professors interest for you to graduate in under 5 years so they will tend to make it difficult.  However there are deadlines set by the university to ensure PhD students do graduate in approximately 5 years so the university will push unwilling professors to help their students graduate in the long run.

pros:
Great educational benefits % retirement benefits (great percentage)
Super-relaxed work environment.
Great camaraderie & after work activities.
Great location, easy commute to the medical school campus
cons:
Salary is weak, raises nonexistent.
Middle management spends all their time thinking about controlling risk, not leadership.
Weak integration of technical staff with academic faculty
Zero value-based management -- if you're not doing it for the money, you should probably be motivated in some other way. Management is clueless in this regard.
Abysmal project management; there is no feeling of accomplishment in completing a project, you are just constantly on "max" -- there is almost no concept of breaking projects down to tasks, and little idea how to prioritize user stories. Tech staff is constantly "jerked around" by faculty whims, management are incapable of standing up to them.

review_title: Decent Benefits, Typical Higher Ed Siloes
job_title: Associate Center Administrator in Chicago, IL
pros: There are a lot of workplace development and career advancement opportunities offered as benefits, as well as yearly tuition assistance. Being a large and successful university, there is a lot of opportunity for lateral moves and promotions if you network to get them. Most of the hiring done (at least in my school) is internal, so making connections makes a difference.
cons: Average salaries are lower than comparable higher ed institutions in the area, and the job grade scale is a joke (ensures that lateral moves will offer you zero extra compensation, and promotion/raises are highly regulated. It's like squeezing water out of a rock). There is some good management, but the siloed structure of the departments/central offices make effecting any change next to impossible.

pros: Northwestern is one of the premier places to do research in nanotechnology. The instruments are state of the art, there are always fantastic seminar speakers, and the access to Argonne National Labs is invaluable. The environment is very collaborative and there is a great graduate student community (at least of the departments that I interact with).
cons: Getting a PhD is a long and laborious process, but it probably isn't much different elsewhere. The weather is terrible and Evanston is not the most interesting town to live in. I commute from the city but it is a hassle during the winter. The summers are much nicer because I can bike in.

review_title: Northwestern culture can vary greatly from dept to dept
pros: First- NU employment varies from dept to dept. In general there is good work/life balance, great benefits (including tuition assistance/reimbursement) and opportunities for advancement. There is access to pretty cool (latest/greatest) cloud, hardware and software with good discounts for employees.
cons:
With that being said, the pay is ok. You can make $10-$20K more outside, easily- especially depending on your role in the organization. The experience can vary from school to school and dept to dept, so much so, it's often like working in another company.
It can be challenging to get a promotion (but not ahead) depending on where you go. You need to make your own career path and advance without help from HR or your manager.

review_title: Administrative positions, build experience, no clear path forward
pros: The benefits of working in higher ed can't be beat. Flexible time, vacation time, sick days, and easy schedules. There are many networking and professional development opportunities at NU. The workplace is generally diverse, inviting and inclusive. You get to work with great students and faculty and this is a gift.
cons: It is difficult for entry level or employees with just their bachelors to move up. Many higher (salaried) positions with the word "director" will require a Masters degree even if that isn't listed in the qualifications. I've been told it is easy to move around at NU but this has not been my experience. Also, education salaries and pay are what they are. It is best if you make the most of your benefits.

review_title: Great for those looking to go into academia
pros: This is an outstanding academic institution and provides wonderful access to faculty and practitioners doing fascinating work. Mentoring opportunities for those looking to continue into academia are abound. Additionally, it is a wealthy institution and provides opportunities for professional development. Fantastic retirement and benefits.
cons:
There may not be upward mobility and as many put it "it is harder to get fired than it is to get promoted; and that is not easy" 
Usually you must threaten to leave the university before they act.
Also, there is a HUGE disconnect between all departments and organizational units at the university which causes disjointed, ineffective, and oftentimes frustrating collaborations.

review_title: Poor Communication and Problems in Core Facilities
pros: Salary and benefits are good and comparable with outside industry.
cons: Very poor communication with staff from administration. Too many private agendas within the various departments. Failed researchers and/or faculty should not be elevated to positions of administration. Duplication of equipment within core facilities and poor management/funding of the core facilities is rampant. Often advise from the experienced employee is overlooked to go down a  fancy and expensive path with a poor outcome. The NUCORE software is a joke. The university invested millions in the Oracle/Peoplesoft platform. Only the Office for Research tried to re-invent the wheel and created the behemoth of NUCORE. How many hundreds of thousands (millions) have they spent on a substandard program. FOM was better. You could customize FOM. The university already owned FOM. Look at all of the other institutions using FOM. Poor leadership in the Office for Research especially Core Facilities.

pros: Great for parents, wonderful colleagues, great benefits and beautiful campus.
cons: When I first started at the University I was told by many people that you have to leave in order to move up in any substantial way, which is very true. The budget crisis has led to a mass exodos of Loyal and hard-working employees who were being overworked, undervalued, and underpaid. With at least 2 more years remaining to the budget crisis, it's not a good place to be right now or anytime soon. Furthermore, the elitism is exhausting and the culture of perfection creates unnecessarily competitive environments.

review_title: great academics and research opportunities... not so great administration and management
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Northwestern is a great university with lots of academic resources and high-quality research. Working here provides the opportunity to interact with very intelligent, prominent professionals from the academic world. Interdepartmental collaboration is particularly strong and a great way to promote advancements and innovations in research. If you are looking to do research, you will find lots of opportunities here.
cons: HR and administration are sometimes really unhelpful and disorganized, depending on your department. My department has a lot of issues with poor communication between employees and administration, with administrators ignoring lots of requests from employees. There is also a good deal of academic snobbery that goes on among the higher-ups.

pros: Great research environment, collegial atmosphere at least in my department on Chicago campus. Efficient in the sense that all mandatory lab safety trainings are available online, supply ordering is efficient, several research core facilities are available to conduct one time experiments on otherwise expensive instruments. Departmental administration is efficient and cooperative. There are lots of networking opportunities for academic/industry positions. The University has a very good reputation in the area, so employers view students/postdocs in positive light during the interview process. Despite being a top research university, the atmosphere is not as cut-throat/intimidating/vicious as other lower ranked and state-funded universities. A good balance of basic and translational research (for biological sciences)
cons: Certain University administrative services like international office/career counseling does not have experienced staff with little knowledge of how to navigate students. Weather in the area is cold for 7-8 months of the year.

pros: Well it's easy to get there with public transportation, good experience to build upon. Management is not always breathing on your neck. Fast paced so it's not boring.
cons: Well, you would think people at this top university would be pretty easy to clean up after, but they are actually just as bad as the elementary school students I used to clean up after. However, as your get higher up in the company you can delegate the responsibilities more to the new people. The management opportunities can lead me to the general manager position or even allow me to apply to other companies. A good place to get some experience and move up at some point.

review_title: Excellent support, that I just wish had started before the quarter began.
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: I taught a large class for a quarter this year. I was pretty nervous, as it was my first time teaching. Fortunately, several of the professors in the department and one assistant in particular (huge thanks, Lana Kiperman) were extremely helpful setting me up with TAs, graders, room scheduling, and anything else I needed. The students were enthusiastic and ready to learn every day.
cons: Unfortunately, I had to wait multiple weeks before an office opened up for me, which given my long commute to Evanston was rather discouraging. That and a few other issues made me wish that I had been in communication with the department earlier to iron them out.

review_title: The experience depends on the department and research group you choose. Overall it was okay, but not for me.
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Chicago, IL
pros: Amazing access to state of the art scientific instrumentation. Many research groups have done a great job in attaining grants that permit you freedom with your project. You don't necessarily have that opportunity at smaller schools.
cons: Professors are not always available so you need to be very proactive with communication. There are so many graduate students in the chemistry department that often you may feel like a number. Again, you have to be proactive to make it the best experience you can.

job_title: Marketing Coordinator in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Great benefits; easy, low-pressure work environment. The people on my particular team were really nice, smart and supportive. Work hours are incredibly reasonable; nobody stays past 5:15 ever.
cons: Incredibly siloed environment; nobody communicates with anyone. There is a general lack of passion and imagination here; it seems to be a place where once-creative or drive professionals are put out to pasture, so to speak, because the benefits and hours are good so people just really come here to chill and build up their 401K.

pros: Working at Northwestern allows you to support the teaching, learning, and research missions of a top-tier institution.  It is nice to know that your efforts, no matter how indirectly, support such a noble cause.  The benefits (particularly retirement plan matching and tuition discounts) are quite good.
cons: The quality of staff, at all levels, varies greatly across units.  Some units are well-organized and able to attract and retain top talent.  Some units have high turnover, due to poor work environments, high usage of entry level staff, or worse.  Other units have "lifers" that need to be managed more diligently, in some cases to retirement or another job/employer.

pros: The benefits are excellent. Healthcare benefits are a bit pricey, but give you access to virtually any doctor. Tuition benefits are also excellent, but later career employees do not really get the full benefit due to their life commitments. Beautiful campus.
cons: My biggest complaint is that the university puts some (poorly performing) faculty in administrative jobs they are not suited to do. They should be doing academic work not managing people. There is always some type of review of the departments going on. Everyone is on pins and needles worrying that they are going to cut jobs and outsource. Janitorial, maintenance, and repair jobs are almost all outsourced. Quality is low. This spreads out to all jobs at NU. Departments are merged and people are let go. And, we have to pay for parking. Morale is so low -- wake up Morty!

job_title: Research Associate in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Good core facilities, lot of big shots (=big money and easy to publish in good papers because they are on the board), lot of private companies recruit on campus (NU is considered a "top school")
cons: Salaries are on the lower side considered it should be a top school, tuition benefits are low (10,000$/year... Kellogg's MBA cost around 150-200K$), some bad stories heard of sexual harrassment (useless to say, NU always tries to "negotiate" with the victim not to make too much noise and supervisors investigated are still on duty... just saying) and NU is a money machine (who said non-profit???). Problem of divided campuses... 45min shuttle from one to the other (no sport/campus entertainment facilities downtown)

review_title: Great Research Institution, Not Great for Career Advancement
pros: Benefits, ability to continue education along with tuition reimbursement, depending on the department you  work at the life/work balance can  be a true thing, and of course research and name
cons: Absolutely no room for advancement, moving up is almost impossible, very high expectations of entry level positions along with heavy work load but apparently the experience does not translate or ensures you to move up higher or getting a promotion, as others have written better to leave and reapply to a higher position, internal employees do not get fair treatment in wanting to advance in their careers and spend years in the same position.

review_title: Strong culture of learning and discovery
job_title: Senior Applications Developer in Evanston, IL
pros: So many opportunities for cross-discipline learning and professional development.  Northwestern is a place you truly fall in love with.  All administration, faculty, staff, students— everyone bleeds Purple and is deeply committed to excellence.
cons: Being a higher-education institution the opportunities to grow academically abound.  Unfortunately, this means the vast majority of staff members are pursuing higher degrees and certification making it more challenging to stand out from the crowd.  As a result, graduate and post-graduate accomplishments are generally not celebrated with promotion and/or raises as one finds in the private sector.

review_title: What you ask for out of the gate is all you'll ever get
pros: Solid benefits, usually easy going work environment. Pay is easily better than other Chicagoland universities. Both Evanston and Chicago campus are near CTA/Metra train lines.
cons: Flat salary potential once hired. Merit increases are typically less than 4%. You need to negotiate a decent starting salary, because HR salary code is designed to hold down salaries even if you're promoted to a position that should pay substantially more. If you take a low pay rate to start, you will always have a low pay rate as long as you're employed at NU regardless of whether you're promoted or transferred.

pros: Great staff to be a part of! I work for the PSV department for Norris Center and it is one of the best decisions I made in college. My coworkers are great and the work is interesting with lots of time to study while at work.
cons: The work is so varied and it is nearly impossible to be trained on everything. A lot of the job requires you to improvise, problem solve and call people for help. It can be a source of anxiety or make you look unprofessional if you don't know how to handle it.

pros: great benefits (educational, insurance, retirement, etc.);  you can earn a bachelors or masters degree basically for free through the wonderful school for continuing studies; lots of room for growth if you are starting off on the lower end;  promotion from within is very common;  beautiful campus ;  good salaries;  lots of opportunities to attend professional development activities;
cons: I worked in the medical school, which I have been told is very different from the main campus.  The environment in the medical school is very demanding;  To do well as a full-time (40 hour/week) staff member, I always had to put in overtime.  Also, in the medical school, I worked for doctors and had to learn quickly how to handle their personality quirks.

pros: Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine has an excellent organizational culture, where labs are conducting cutting-edge research in a very collaborative and supportive environment. As a technician, the work-life balance is great. Time off and all other benefits are much better than anywhere else I had interviewed. Overall a very positive work experience.
cons: Very little room for advancement. Salaries, though competitive compared to other educational institutions, are still very low especially given Chicago's high cost of living. Yearly merit increases are kept standard throughout institution -- giving the chance for employees to deserve higher raises would provide added incentive to perform beyond regular job requirements.

review_title: Variety of positions at various skill levels, but needs some updating
pros: Great benefits and flexible schedule.  Certain areas of the university really value their employees.
cons: The pay is not competitive and the university does not fire anyone so bad workers are just moved around or stay on their positions too long.  The university is also behind the times in terms of technology and renovation of the various buildings.  Some areas are more than 50 years old and are in desperate need of updating and modernization.

review_title: Former research coordinator - Northwestern Medical School Department of Radiology
job_title: Research Project Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: The medical school certainly has the money to spread around on important projects. I was not lacking for supplies.
cons: The relationship between Northwestern's Feinberg School of Medicine and Northwestern Memorial Hospital and the Rehab Institute is complicated and bureaucratic. If you work for the university but need a password or access to ANYTHING on the hospital side, prepare yourself for a nightmare of clearances and having to "go behind' the gatekeepers to do your job.

job_title: Administrative Assistant IV in Evanston, IL
pros: Benefits, time off, exposure to top-notch academic research,
cons:
Main issues that stand out:
- No room for advancement or career growth (people  literally stuck in their positions). I saw really good and dedicated employees leave NU just because they could not move up.  
- Micromanaging supervisors - many; they drive the productivity down
- Archaic performance reviews - this is what I saw happened with performance reviews at NU: Performance review instill a culture of fear. They tend to demoralize and demotivate employees. And if your manager does not like you you are screwed.

job_title: Office Manager (/Office Assistant) for CTD Leapfrog/Spark in Evanston, IL
pros:
Hired with no prior work experience (other than babysitting)

Opportunities to work with children, but not primarily responsible for them

Medium-energy position with high-energy periods - minor emergencies flare up, but it's mostly humdrum administrative work

Management (at least the people you interact with) are very competent, pleasant people

Job security - every spring, CTD sends offers to well-performing O.A.'s, no need to re-apply
cons:
High staff turnover in low-level/summer-only positions (summer-only staff are HS/college students who move on to higher-level positions elsewhere).

Difficult to build connections with individual students.

Job can be tedious during slow parts of day; bring a book

Most O.A. positions are off-campus, but if you get hired for the on-campus position, you will spend much of June crouched in a warm, stuffy, dark basement, sorting supplies into boxes. Bring music and you'll be good.

review_title: It used to be a great place to work
job_title: Training Specialist/Instructional Designer in Chicago, IL
pros: Great work/life balance, friendly atmosphere, low stress, laid back environment. Great educational benefits. Retirement match is terrific.
cons: On boarding is an inconsistent experience. Training is not mandatory and thus many new employees struggle through their work or end up leaving. Once you're an employee they do very little to retain you, promote you, etc. The annual review process is very demoralizing and your annual increase for doing a good job is usually less than 3%. A new executive vice president is now running thinks like a corporation and ruining what used to be a great place to work.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Northwestern’s Cancer Center seems to really value staff professional development. They’re big into meetings and trainings.
cons: Staff retention is very poor. People leave after 3 months, 6 months, or many under a year. Very few people have been here more than a couple years. The management, while well structured compared to other universities, is very poorly executed, and no one ever seems to know what they’re doing. There are huge gaps when you start because people just don’t do their work, and at a large organization, you can never as one person work enough to fix things that many people have neglected for years. You’re a number not a person here, and everyone just does enough to get by, not actually thrive or succeed.

review_title: Good benefits and stipend for most programs (but not all)
job_title: PhD Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: NU has provided a fairly reasonable salary, but the most helpful has been the paternity leave benefits. When my son was born, I received a full quarter of funding (3 months) from The Graduate School as the father and I have access to childcare grants on a quarterly basis as well as childcare grants for the additional childcare needed when I travel for a conference and my wife needs extra help.
cons: As with many graduate schools, the experience can vary considerably by program. Not all programs have guaranteed funding through their 6th year and some require students to do much more teaching.

review_title: World-class medical research institute in a great city
pros: top-notch scientists, great support staff, lots of funding, and the Chicago campus is located right by the beautiful Lake Michigan
cons: When compared to other academic institutes I can't think of any. The Winter weather can be brutal in Chicago.

pros: Northwestern University offers a great education, has stellar students, faculty and staff and has a strong growing, global reputation. Employees have access to interesting speakers and courses.  Many work in offices within walking distance of Lake Michigan. We have a new president who has added new life to the institution.
cons: Northwestern is made up of multiple semi-autonomous schools which makes doing anything in an integrated fashion very difficult. There is a strong divide between faculty and staff which can feel like a caste system at times. The enterprise is slow to respond to changing expectations and needs of customers - including prospective students, parents and employers of our graduates.

job_title: Graduate Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: A great deal of support from other members in the field I was working in at Northwestern. Great access to necessary instrumentation for the most part. Fantastic opportunities for outside lab activities. The Evanston campus is far enough away from Chicago to be pretty relaxed and safe, while students have the option to ride the L into the city for fun. Frequent events for graduate students to get out of lab.
