cons: The school always seems to be competing with UofC and coming up a bit short. The health insurance offered graduate students could be improved. Greater monetary compensation would make living in Chicago more reasonable.

review_title: Not a bad place to be
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Evanston, IL
pros: The atmosphere here is very positive and collaborative.  There are lots of opportunities for professional development if you seek them out.  People are willing to help.
cons: Nobody wants to be stuck in graduate school forever.  Poor work/life balance.  Can't clock out and stop worrying about work.  Designing experiments, analyzing data, drawing conclusions, and putting it all into written an oral communications, all on a time crunch can be quite stressful.

pros: I spent a year and a half working at Northwestern University Library. Pros are what you'd expect: very intelligent, knowledge-driven colleagues; respect and appreciation for goals beyond the purely financial; great benefits, and not stressful at all.
cons: Again, mostly what you'd expect: things tended to move very slowly, as all projects had to be completed by the book (ha). Fixation on detail slowed work down further and meant that strategies were difficult to formulate. Also, a MLS degree was required for the vast majority of positions, creating a large financial barrier for many.

review_title: Challenging work, in both good and not-so-good ways
pros: I learned a great deal about my abilities while working here and expanded my skill set significantly. Great location in Evanston, benefits are terrific, and colleagues are great people. Plenty of opportunities for learning and campus engagement outside work, too. Loved being able take classes with my tuition benefits and see concerts, plays and movies on campus for less.
cons: Low transparency in decision-making from senior administration, though how much your supervisor is willing to share with you matters immensely here and that varies by department. A highly political environment, especially the higher up the org chart you go.

pros: This is a great place for teachers to work. Working with gifted students is a treat after a long week of teaching, and the faculty and staff is extremely supportive. They are also very open to running new classes designed by the teachers, so there is a lot of autonomy and creative opportunities if sought out.
cons: The pay is not great compared to other part-time teaching positions, but the experience makes it worth the effort. It is also difficult to work on Saturdays if you coach a sport for your full-time teaching job.

review_title: NU is great if you want to maintain work/life balance, and just clock in and out without investing
pros: The benefits are great with lots of time off, tuition discounts, and a culture that encourages you to take care of yourself and your family first. It's wonderful if you have a different priority in your life like an acting career, going back to school or taking care of your family.
cons: Change and innovation are painstakingly slow. Sometimes it's hard to get your job done well with all the bureaucratic red tape. Other administrators are more concerned with covering their bases than helping you, or more importantly, the students. I feel like it's weird that I care as much as I do. I wish that wasn't the case.

review_title: Love working here but very few advancement opportunities and annual review process is poor.
pros: Pleasant working environment, friendly colleagues, flexible hours, excellent benefits.
cons: Advancement opportunities are hard to come by. Receiving a more favorable review on Performance Excellence than the year before does not guarantee a larger yearly raise. As an example, one year I received a 4/6 rating and got over 3%.  The next year I received a 5/6 and got below 3%. The Performance Excellence program does not adequately reward employees for striving for excellence.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Nice lake view. Lots of collaboration opportunities, especially we are close to Argonne. People here are nice. Chicago is (kind of) an interesting place (as compared to... say Urbana!). Nice gym. Shuttle service convenient for students.
cons: I am not feeling excited about the library - often I can't find the book I want. Laboratory often suffer from power outage. High cost of living. They care about research work much more than course work (this maybe a pro!). Often times I encounter a journal I am not able to access. Software support (Matlab, mathematica, etc) for students needs improvement!

review_title: Hit-and-miss management and staff, but growth opportunities for those who seek them out
pros:
A large university that is almost always hiring for a wide variety of staff positions.  As an entry-level or early career employee, it can be easy to rise quickly if you excel at your job, BUT this depends on your department management.  In some instances there may be more opportunities for rapid growth than in corporate, since there frankly isn't much competition among lower-level staff (or upper management, for that matter).  It's easy to find things that could be improved and implement procedures to improve them - but you may have to fight for recognition afterward.

Outstanding benefits.  Automatic 5% contribution towards retirement, plus the university will match your contribution up to an additional 5%.  That means you can contribute 5% of your income to retirement and actually be saving 15% per year.

75-80% tuition benefit.  The School of Continuing Studies has some good evening certificate and graduate programs for working professionals (though classes may be offered only in Evanston, or only in Chicago, at any given time).  

They are *trying* to be more progressive when it comes to staff, hosting networking and professional development events and the like.
cons:
Faculty can be downright rude and disrespectful; stay away from positions that deal with faculty if you can help it.  I cannot emphasize this enough.  They also have no idea how to be administrators or work with staff, and the learning curve is steep every time a faculty member takes on an administrative role.

Somewhat rigid HR policies concerning raises and promotions, values years of experience over performance.  

Senior staff love them some bureaucracy.  Getting any changes implemented takes forever.  Very hierarchical management, I don't think they've ever heard of "moving towards a flatter organizational structure."  

No one ever loses their job, even people who EVERYONE knows would have been fired long ago in the private sector.  This lowers morale.

Staff are a weird mix of folks - some very professional, motivated and talented people, and then a lot of folks who are just like characters from "The Office" (think Dwight, Angela, and Creed types).

There are some great individuals on the IT team, but the way the whole IT operation is run is insane.  The individual school IT departments have WAY too much autonomy, creating huge disparities between schools when it comes to software upgrades, websites, etc.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
pros: Great school to get a research posistion at, slightly worse at undergrad. Student jobs are easy to find and there are several types - the libraries if you want to get work done, Norris center if you want to make a tight group of friends.
cons: Mostly the people are great, it's the IT that's bad. They use Kronos, which is a mess and you can only access on NU internet, and the process of getting any tax forms online is so messed up that I gave up on trying.

job_title: Research Technologist I in Chicago, IL
pros: Some people in lab are fun and want to be friendly
cons: Be mindful of which PIs you work for. Some want to extort and take advantage of new graduates by under paying them and emotionally abusing them. A lot of labs do not follow guidelines and IUPAC protocol unless there is a check in. Very emotionally abusive work environment. If you're in a lab and unhappy with the lab and want to switch, it is virtually impossible due to spiteful PIs who won't let you leave and give bad recommendations to other PIs but they don't want to fire you so they continue to extort and take advantage of you.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: Very nice place to be. Beautiful campus and a lot of supporting facilities for all kinds of student and staff activities. The compensation rate for the position I am in is fair if compared to other universities, but certainly much lower than it could have been in the private sector. Research labs generally have money for conducting decent scientific work.
cons: The overall experience depends a lot on the person you are working with. It can be a huge boost to the academic career if the advisor is active in his/her field and the field is fresh and modern. Otherwise, it might feel like a dead end and force you to consider employment elsewhere in the private sector.

pros: My experience is as a postdoc, so my salary has little to do with Northwestern's policies. They provide decent enough insurance coverage options, which I assume are pretty standard across universities in the US. They have a donation matching program for your HSA (for the first year), which I loved. The faculty and staff are all professional, helpful, and friendly.
cons: A few organizational issues here and there, but this is probably very particular to the department in which you happen to work. Postdocs in general are kind of an anomaly in the US education system (still) -- many departments still struggle to know how to handle some of the basic paperwork, funding issues, etc.

review_title: There is a lot to achieve if one is willing to work hard.
job_title: PhD Student In Mechanical Engineering in Evanston, IL
pros: There is a diverse group of faculty with a broad range of research interests. Each professor has their own advising unique style, hence it is difficult to relate my personal experiences to others. If one is not satisfied with their adviser, they can always switch, and there are so many great people here to find to work with.
cons: The graduate pay is not as great. Career services here are always very busy so one has to primarily rely on themselves to get a job. Also, one has to be willing to self motivate themselves to work long hours if they hope to graduate within four years.

pros: Good, flexible hours. Pleasant work environment. Professors are understanding of student obligations and time. Overall, a very positive and rewarding experience if you are a student.
cons: Downsides are very few - I think this is a good position to be in. I think that if it would be possible to pay people more, that would be a good thing, but it's understandable that the wage is not very high, especially given the flexibility of the job.

review_title: Northwestern is overall a well-run - but not perfect - university
pros:
Strong research institution in great financial state, impression of administration largely positive.

Good benefits, non-NRSA postdocs treated as full employees:
- Solid and relatively inexpensive health and dental insurance
- Matching retirement up to 5% plus 5% employer contribution for employees with 1+ years service
- Good parental leave - four weeks paid for employees with 3+ years service
cons:
- Postdoc salary is low (same as everywhere)
- Northwestern is perhaps a hair more bureaucratic than other research institutions I've worked at - emphasis on paper forms, etc.
- Northwestern is pretty 'small c' conservative
- (Mixed) Support for core labs is not amazing, but improving

review_title: Northwestern University is a great company to work for
job_title: Project Coordinator II in Chicago, IL
pros: The benefits especially retirement is one of the best in the area.  Time off is fair and generally easy to get, especially since most positions allow for flexible scheduling.
cons: Everything positive or negative about the NU is very dependent on the department you work for.  My department was horrible.  The pay was bad (especially for the area), there was no advancement opportunity and the management was pathetic.  NU HR was aware of all of this and either had no power to change or didn't care enough.

pros: None.  I worked in research at the medical school.  This place has the worst politics of any employer.
cons: They steal your ideas.  They don't compensate you.  They drum up lies to get you to leave.  They have an anti-male agenda as well.  The double standards with this group & the pattern of defamation as a tool to pressure people to quiet is not only unfair & biased, it is arrogantly trumpeted as a strength by an organization so busy patting itself on the back, it's lost the capacity for self evaluation.  Do not work for the Medical School.  The world would be a better place, & your tax dollars would be better spent, if it no longer existed.

review_title: While I liked my office, I felt that the university overall did not value its employees.
job_title: Program Assistant II in Evanston, IL
pros: Low stress environment, world renowned university. It is a beautiful campus with a good reputation which helped me get my next job.
cons: HR is atrocious, terrible salary, horrible benefits. During an HR presentation the head of HR told us that in order to get better maternity leave and childcare options, it would need to be federally mandated. They just weren't very concerned with being a school that values its staff. I knew about this from speaking with academic employees as well. We were all dealing with sub par working compensation.

review_title: Northwestern is a great to be a graduate student: a fantastic school located a short train ride from an awesome city.
pros: Very strong academic credentials, and a competitive stipend (for STEM fields, at any rate). Social environment depends a lot on which specific research group you join, as well as the department, so that is difficult to predict, but my experience has been extremely positive.
cons: This goes for all graduate studies, really, but the entire tenure system means that your boss has zero accountability to you. This can be really really bad if you have an adviser who is more interested in their own prestige than your success, so pick your group carefully!

pros: Of course it's the benefits and access to great research, and educational assistance
cons: Forget it - no career advancement. Don't fool yourself, once you're an assistant it is very heard to move up anywhere in this place. You're stuck, unless you know someone who really can make things happen for you. Rarely did I see anyone from any assistant positions to move up, other than another assistant position. Pay is low compared to other schools for the same position. They offer workshops and career management classes that are great since they will point you in the right direction, but will not help you move up in this place.

review_title: Mixed bag of good and bad
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Evanston, IL
pros: Great tuition benefits and retirement plan. Decent people on occasion. Not all areas of NU have cons.
cons: Must play politics to advance in some departments, high turnover, low pay, no work life balance for some. Hard to fire incompetent staff which is bad for morale. Annual raises are around 2% for top performers, but expect zero to 1 % on average.

job_title: Full-time Faculty Or Administrative Work in Chicago, IL
pros: I have been afforded many opportunities to grow in the job and to accept new challenges.  There have been good bosses that have given me freedom to innovate..Life/work balance has always been good.
cons:
We are constantly asked to do more with less.  
Incompetent individuals tend to be shuffled to new positions. Some hires seem to be based on "who you know" rather than any experience or skill set which is demoralizing when one is expected to work with/for someone who is both ignorant and powerful.

job_title: Research Data Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Prestige, Location, Fast Commute, Good Health Insurance.
cons: This was my first job after graduating college. The salary for the posistion I applied to was not explicitly stated in the application, and I did not learn about it until my now direct supervisor made me an offer. I accepted the offer under the condition that HR would have final say on my pay, and they ended up offering me 10K less. At that point, I had already made plans to move to Chicago, and reluctantly accepted it. I felt low balled by the offer, and upset my supervisor and HR were not in agreement before giving me an offer.

review_title: Wonderful family atmosphere where you get to meet a LOT of NU alumni
job_title: Director of Marketing in Evanston, IL
pros: Fun Good networking, team perspective.  Access to professional development and leading industry knowledge..  Good place to implement cutting edge social media and networking tools.  Great benefits too
cons: Low pay for the amount of work you do!   There could be more respect for work/life balance.  They expect you to put in a 40 week and then work events on the weekends and that can be hard, especially in the fall.

review_title: NU offers a wealth of opportunities if you are proactive and choose to make use of all their resources.
job_title: Research Study Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: This varies widely depending on which department you work in and what you do. In my experience in the Psychology Department, all university systems work very effectively and efficiently. I've been very impressed with the sense of academic community and willingness to take risk on the part of graduate students, post docs, and faculty.  On top of it all, the benefits are really great.
cons: At times, beaurocracy can interfere with getting work done, so I end up spending a lot of time preparing work early to compensate for impending beaurocracy.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Department resources and staff are second to none.  Department has a good track record of supporting its students when student-advisor relations become dire.
cons: Of course, student-advisor relations have to become dire before any meaningful intervention happens in the first place.  Mine had a lot of leeway to be particularly unprofessional and mean.  Faculty need to have their hands held by The Graduate School in order to effectively manage their students.

pros: Good work-life balance. Pays well for higher ed. Good benefits (pre-covid). Nice co-workers. Lots of events and free food. The response to COVID has been amazing. Senior leadership has been very transparent and has shown they are committed to prioritizing employee safety and well-being during this difficult time.
cons: Even though every person I've worked with has been extremely nice, the micromanagement culture runs deep. Employees aren't trusted to make their own decisions or contributions. Department managers have to approve every single decision and will redo all your work to be in line with their own preferences. It creates a really demoralizing culture, because specialists aren't valued for their knowledge and expertise and aren't allowed to contribute to projects in a meaningful way. There's also a bit of cliquishness on certain teams. People who are BFFs with management are given the challenging and meaningful work, and their opinions get prioritized over the opinions of actual subject-matter experts. This is especially problematic when you realize that some cliques seem to form around lines of race, gender, and marital/parental status. This marginalizes employees who don't fit certain demographics, because while the clique members get all the good assignments, employees outside the clique are given low-level tasks that only very weakly relate to the job they were hired for, such as being hired for a technology role but then being asked to perform duties the administrative assistant would normally do merely because it involves using a website. If you're looking for an easy job where you just show up and do as you're told, then this is the place for you. If you're looking for career growth, advancement, and autonomy, look elsewhere, because you won't find it here.

job_title: Program Assistant III in Evanston, IL
pros: Decent pay and great benefits. The work was not at all demanding, and the day always ended at 5 PM.
cons: Wonderful professors and students but a typically stilted, snail-paced, bureaucratic place to work as an admin.

job_title: Lead IT Analyst in Evanston, IL
pros: Great job for work-study (and even non-work-study) students.  They pay you when your work-study funding is depleted, which is often about halfway through the school year.  It teaches many useful skills, and certainly challenges you to grow and develop yourself to succeed.
cons: Not a job at which you can do homework.  It is also sometimes a bit stressful, especially when you're quite busy and there are more people calling in.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Evanston, IL
pros: The working hours are very flexible and there are great opportunities to meet many top scientists in the (chemical) field.
cons: Management (Chemistry) is horribly disillusioned and will not address the needs of the students that contribute to the department. Students are at the mercy of their research adviser who is usually  so focused on submitting work to a specific journal that they do not advise at all.

review_title: Great company - experience depends on colleagues
pros:
- Decent compensation, fantastic benefits
- Colleagues and students are intelligent and hard-working
cons:
- Stagnancy is visible; some staff and managers are not focused on improvement
- Staff can become complacent, and some are incompetent in their roles; the damage they cause to a department or organization has a lasting impact, and directly affects University services

job_title: Senior Program Coordinator in Evanston, IL
pros: Benefits are good but being trimmed, potential for flexible schedule, potential to learn new skills on the job
cons: Limited advancement within the organization, culture varies widely from department to department and group to group, administratively seems behind the times - like working at a company in the 1990s. Many changes have occurred over the past few years. Very little cross-training or uniform training.

job_title: Manager, Talent Acquisition in Evanston, IL
pros: NU has phenomenal benefits and overall provides a great work life balance. There is great access to resources for career growth and opportunities.
cons: Some of the great benefits were recently impacted such as the retirement match. This has been temporarily suspended and I do not see this being reinstated for some time. The retirement match wait period has also been changed from 1 year to 2 years which will make it more difficult for new hires to be enticed by the match (if and when it is reinstated). As it is with every company, you have some great supervisors and not so great.

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Evanston, IL
pros: I really enjoyed the research that I took part in. Things were never done in a silo and the work really benefited from efforts by a diverse team of researcher backgrounds. Benefits are good- decent paid leave and medical benefits. Parking on campus was too pricey for me but public transportation is pretty good around there.
cons: They seemed to talk a lot about how you can move up and around the company but I never really saw that where I worked.

pros:
- Good Benefits
- Variety of opportunities exist in many subjects
- Opportunity to get education from a top university at minimal cost
cons:
-  while management promotes professional development, only the favored staff are actually able to take advantage of training and development opportunities
-  work load is very uneven, i.e. some teams routinely work 50 - 60 hours a week while other teams only work the standard 37.5
-  managers with poor management skills
-  obvious favoritism shown in treatment of employees

review_title: Pretends to be a great place to work; I know a lot about it as I've been working there for 10 years.
pros:
If you work long enough and your children get excepted to NU, you can benefit from the tuition reduction that is generally ridiculously high.

It's hard to be fired if you do nothing but say "Hi" and "Bye" to superiors, work 9 to 5, never have any ideas and never contradict those who are in charge.
Very political, and politically correct, very bureaucratic, very unfair unless you meet certain "requirements" for staying.

Good benefits comparing to other places.
cons:
If you have talents, abilities to create things, if you really care about the students (who very often are prima donna style students), if you have your principles, run away from that place.

Salaries suck comparing to other Universities. If you are a staff member, you'll be seriously underpaid. Everyone, no matter who you are, how many years you dedicated to the University is replaceable. 

The best NU internal joke: "It's like a beautiful girl. Looks good, treats you like sh..."

Many top managers don't have enough education to even get the positions of Deans, Associate Deans, Master Degree program directors and if you are more educated than them--guess what? You are fired or they create such an environment for you that you leave.

Many professors don't have Master's degree, some of them did not have even Bachelor's degree in the field. Is not that a shame for the University that pretends being part of IVY League? Students complain about those instructors but if they meet University "spirit", they will never publish those complaints. 


I can go on and on but will add just one thing---some of their best alums will never give University any money--I know that for a fact. The University never became a dear place for them.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Evanston, IL
pros:
Excellent facilities for a university lab, so one can learn a lot there.
The transfer of knowledge and training is very efficient, people become productive very fast and can publish a lot.
cons:
Management based on fear, which creates a very poor atmosphere in the lab.
Students and postdocs are often threatened of being fired in order to get more work out of them.
At CQD PhD students are supposed to stay in the lab all the time (even on saturday), and activities for personal or scientific development outside the lab are discouraged.
Finally, creativity is very limited in this lab, as new ideas are not welcome.

pros:
*Employees at Kellogg
*Activities at Kellogg/NU
*Temp workers are very competent
cons:
*Can only temp 1000 hours in a year
*Applying online is a lie
*Cannot get hired due to too much internal politics
*Do not take people at their word to help you, b/c they will NOT.
*Temp workers are paid less than full time workers hourly.
*Temp center is run by fools.

review_title: Good work life, but experience may depend on department/school
pros: Schedule (M-F 8:30-5), decent benefits
cons: Have to wait 1 year after starting a job to transfer, salaries are not competitive with what one would get in corporate world unless you work at Medical School. When I recently applied for a job within my department that would have been considered a promotion, I was told after the fact there was a limit on how much my salary could increase. My salary is less than the midpoint for the position, so it seems like I would have been better off had I not already worked within the department.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: In addition to being one of the best chemistry departments in the country, Northwestern pays it's students quite well (relatively speaking) and provides decent health insurance. The esteemed nature of the department is also beneficial in the grant writing process and reviewers very favorable towards the departments "atmosphere" or environment. Almost all of the research groups are well-funded and doing world-class research!
cons: The biggest problem with working at Northwestern is the layout of Evanston with respect to restaurants. Zoning laws in evanston leave few good choices within walking distance from campus (food trucks are also prohibited). For a graduate student, this is a pretty serious source of concern. ;)

review_title: Underwhelmed with the experience, direction and competence of the department
job_title: Senior Business Systems Analyst in Evanston, IL
pros: Good benifits, liberal sick day policy. Laid back university environment, no expectations of success or competency.
cons: Quality of peers work was poor, no one to learn from professionally and the more talented team members tended to leave. The technical level of the staff did not match what I expected from a university of this renound.

review_title: Good opportunity for personal development, convoluted administration.
job_title: Research Technician II in Evanston, IL
pros: They provide some of the best benefits available, especially the tuition benefit.  There are ample resources available to grow in your career if you are self-motivated and self-directed.
cons: Administrative procedures are confused and convoluted,  Turf wars seem to abound between departments and administration.  The tenure system has enthroned too many professors who think they have earned the right to treat non-faculty poorly, and badger the administration when they don't get exactly what they want.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: 1.The people in Northwestern are in general nice people. 2. My works are heavily involved in some research, so there are a lot of challenging and stimulating problems to solve everyday. 3. Also, the community around the school is superb to live.
cons: The weather is bad in winter. It gets really cold and windy for seven to eight months every year. But you will be ok once you are mentally and physically prepared for that.

review_title: Good benefits, fair treatment of post docs.
pros:
Good benefits, fair treatment of post docs. Northwestern's name recognition is extraordinary-- everyone in the Chicago area seems to respect Northwestern. In my particular field, NU's reputation is strong, and I've found that this can open doors.

After one year many postdocs qualify for retirement benefits. Health, vision, and dental benefits also seem pretty reasonable. Not great, but the situation could be much worse for postdocs.

This will all vary by your field, department, and lab, but my boss is reasonable. I'm pushed to complete my work, but my boss understands balance. Depending on which department you're, you might be able to take advantage of  excellent job-hunting resources offered to postdocs. Northwestern does a pretty good job of preparing it's post docs for the next step.  

You wouldn't want to work here as a postdoc forever, but for 1-4 years, you could do a lot worse. With any luck, you'll leave with a great set of skills and contacts, as well as the Northwestern name on your CV. There are plenty of cons (see below), but if you're looking for a job for a few years, you don' t have lofty academic goals,  and you still like ramen noodles, Northwestern is a decent place to be.
cons:
These cons are specific to my experience as a postdoc in one of the physical sciences. My work is almost 100% research, and at NU it's impossible to build any momentum. As soon as my experiments start working, I seem to have to stop work to deal with: (1) bureaucratic hurdles or (2) instruments that are broken or too heavily booked. Work that can take days at other universities can take weeks or months here.

The bureaucratic hurdles mean that ordering lab supplies is a nightmare-- it can take a week (or more) to place an order, and after the package is delivered to campus it can take days to receive it. As for instrument time, if you use shared equipment  you might find that you need to book time more than one week in advance. It can take weeks to shift gears if your goals change suddenly.  I find myself plodding along when I'm dying to sprint. If you're a "slow and steady" type, or you relish filling out forms, this could be the place for you! 

There's lots of good stuff about Northwestern (see above), but I find that the expectations here are quite high, and the resources available make reaching those expectations almost impossible. These cons are particular my particular physical science.

review_title: It has been a great developmental and learning experience
job_title: Senior Consultant In Information Technology in Evanston, IL
pros: Working in Information technology at Northwestern is a great experience because of the people you work with, the knowledge you gain about how to work for when you're not longer a student and the experience with customer support.
cons: There is a lot of oversight and concern about not messing up. This kind of focus can get to be a little bit overwhelming at times since you have to manage such a huge array of information. However, this is an understandable thing for this type of job and doesn't really take away from the enjoyment.

review_title: Full of kind, passionate people- room for promotion, growth, and professional development
pros: At NU, on the staff side, you are paid well, there is tons of room for professional development and growth. Work-life balance is maintainable. There are lots of young people, so there are lots of friends to be made for recent college grads. Evanston is a nice place to work and live.
cons: As with any academic institution, there is red tape and a sort of bureaucracy that can be difficult to deal with. There is almost no parking on this campus. If you want to park, you have to pay to park.

pros: Convenient...easy come, easy go.  Revolving door - good when you are between jobs, nice to know NU is around.  2-1 403b match is good.
cons: Academics are mean and nasty people - especially in Feinberg.  Pay is not the greatest.  Feinberg also has a lot of nasty premeds working there -  they are vicious.

job_title: Senior Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Working at NU, specifically the FSM, allows you many opportunities to work with incredibly driven and brilliant researchers/doctors. There are numerous opportunities to enhance your CV and knowledge base, as well as to network with other departments
cons: Moving up within NU (not so much lateral moves), in my experience, has been difficult. Rather than administration at your individual department approving promotions, your department has to campaign for the promotion with HR executives, if the position does not seem to fit EXACTLY with HR's definition of the duties and qualifications.

pros: If you have a passion for research there is interesting and exciting research that is being done in all specialty areas. Great benefits.
cons: There currently is a big transition in leadership at the institution that has created a sense of uncertainty due to lack of unauthentic direction of plan. Very little opportunity to move up.

review_title: Resource Rich, but a Challenging Culture
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros:
-Better base PhD funding than most
-Lower teaching burden than most
-Campus on lake
-Prestige of name
-Resources exist for those willing and able to doggedly hunt/network for them
cons:
-Poor communication between administration, academic departments, other departments, potential resources; one hand does not know what the other hand is doing
-Lack of adequate teaching support
-Administration's estimate of how much time TAs actually spend on TA responsibilities comically low
 -Lack of affordable housing nearby-->lengthy commute
-Campus and most resources designed for undergrads
-Illogical leave policy
-poor handicap accessibility
-Corporate environment

pros: NU has a prestigious reputation; you will gain notable experience in higher education practices working for this university. The reputation keeps outstanding individuals coming to work for them; you can expect to work with some top talent. Pleasant working environments in Evanston and Chicago campuses, and parking is quite reasonable. Security is well implemented on campus and provides a safe working environment.  The college offers a significant tuition reimbursement opportunity, as a staff member you have excellent educational opportunities. Great place to work short term, with the right exit strategy, and can leverage this job experience to obtain employment in an organization that does over advancement opportunity.
cons:
For management this is a difficult work environment to implement change within, the University has key deficiencies in knowledge management, resource sharing, and IT governance. IT literally runs 10-15 years behind; I have even seen use of obsolete technology. For staff this is a very demanding environment, with little work life balance, 50-60 hour workweeks are not uncommon. Non competitive pay, I've seen merit increases at NU that are less then a cost a living increase, even for top performers.

While NU's reputation attracts top talent, it seems to provide little long-term benefit since best and brightest employees are quick to leave, when they realize there is little opportunity for growth. The rate of turn over is outrageous, and strains department productivity and moral. I literally saw an entire department turn over in less then a year.

Somme of the top management and leadership at NU are resistant to change, it appeared to me that they were clinging to politically driven agendas or their own vested interests, which directly resulted in errors in judgment, resulting in loss of revenue. The command and control leadership style has created a culture of fear and blame, resulting in poor communication within departments. Each department focuses on their own goals and interests. Department interdependencies remain completely overlooked in the evaluation process, each department works for itself, and fail to see how their practices works against the other or for the other. Several times I witness a department implement changes, which were never communicated, and caused critical issues for other departments.

Quite honestly it appears some schools within the university are in pattern of decline: little change, out-dated technology, high turn over, lack of credibility in leadership, and overstrained resources abound.  Leadership is defiantly lacking.

pros: Great benefits that don't compare to other companies.
cons: Lower pay due to non-profit status (even though the school is LOADED).  You have to learn a lot of regulations and policy, and the University seems to be changing policy every minute- often without communicating the changes.  Culture is very dependent on where you work: each school is different, and central offices (e.g. HR) tend to be more corporate-like.

job_title: Animal Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: Great for starting a career in biomedical research! I wouldn't make this my job role for no more than two years. Get certified as soon as you can! Once you obtain one, start studying for the next. Network with lab personnel and Principal Investigators, ask them questions, show your interest! It's like having a chance to communicate with some of the most brightest and intelligent individuals! The more information you already know, the more information they are willing to provide. You MUST be  a diversified individual in order to "make it" in the field of science, anywhere...period. AHT Staff are GREAT! GREAT veterinarians, they take care of business.  If you don't like mice or the smell of animals, please do not bother to waste this departments time or money.
cons: Do not overwork yourself or do NOT mention too much about your advanced education or future desires to advance academically ( in the field of science). This particular role within the department is only a way to get your foot in the door and keep it open long enough to get some fresh air. Do NOT make "friends" with your immediate coworkers! Stay NEUTRAL!  Some management staff ( Group Leaders especially )within the department have obtained their jobs through ole-school politics or being connected to someone else in the field who gave them a chance ...a long long long time ago...not because they had intentions to pursue the field biomedical research immediately after high school graduation...share ideas but not too many because it appear like you are trying to run the show. not good.

review_title: Fine institution in a fantastic location!
pros: Northwestern is centrally located two blocks east of Michigan Avenue on Chicago.  Students that live more than two miles from school are given the opportunity to park on campus for the extremely affordable rate of $400/year.  Students are also given the UPass for free public transportation on the CTA.  Northwestern supplements the cost of a yearly membership at Holmes Place gym so that students only pay $130/year.  Aside from those non-academic reasons to enjoy being a graduate student at Northwestern, I have found that the NU community to be incredibly supportive.  Students and faculty are always more than eager to help eachother out, whether it be with sharing equipment, reagents or constructive criticism.
cons: I listed the location of Northwestern as being a great reason to work at Northwestern.  However, if you wish to live close to work, it will be very expensive.  Unfortunately, this means that you will either end up with a very small apartment, or you will be living a few miles away from the school.  Medical insurance does exist, but doesn't cover everything you would think it should cover.  Dental insurance is not provided, but is available if you choose to pay for it.  As for the academic community, most of the facilities are top notch, but beware, some buildings are in serious need to being updated.

review_title: don't go to grad school, get a job
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: Professors are very smart but very busy, sometimes not concerned with your development.  Get an older one who has already built up their career.
cons: If you work for a new prof they're building their career on your back.

pros: Great 403b contribution, good starting salaries, non-technical interview process based on personality.
cons: No direction, No focus, poor mentoring, poor encouragement.  Teams are split into as little as 1 or 2 people.  Managers are unable to make decisions and stick with them.

job_title: Research Study Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Great benefits (ed, health, dental, vision, commuter, retirement, etc.), lots of research jobs, intercampus shuttle with a stop in Rogers Park, for those close to there, casual research environment, interesting research.
cons: No real cons at this point but I am currently underemployed in the job, and not compensated commensurate with all that I bring to the table. Also, I am not eligible for a transfer to a position, which is a better fit, until I have been in my current position for at least a year. The latter would not be any different anywhere, I assume.

review_title: Amazing place to learn and work.
pros: Northwestern University is a great place to learn. It have so many facilities with a lot of scientific capabilities. It also has a large number of distinguished professors  who adds a lot to the value of this academic institution.
cons: A better health insurance policy is required specially for graduate students. As a big institution communication with higher management levels may be difficult.

pros: Employees receive a very nice discount on tuition
cons: Only 5 days of vacation after the first 6 months.   3 weeks of vacation only after you have been there a year.  The director of my department had no background in IT and no background in management. No flexible hours. The culture of my department was horrific.  The director has a prison mentality.  Everyone that worked in that department was guilty until proven innocent.  They did not know or follow established IT work flow or processes. Management does not promote free thinking.  I experienced cronyism, sexism, racism, and discrimination from all managers I worked with.

pros: Amazing benefits, 401k employer match, plus another 5 percent non-match by the university. 3 weeks vacation after the first year, plus very flexible hours in my position.
cons: Very political. I find that I never talk to my head of the department even when we work in a very small (less than 20) people department. A lot of kissing ass and trying to look good to their supervisors. No team work environment what-so-ever.

review_title: Northwestern makes sure to take care of its graduate students professionally
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: NU offers excellent guaranteed tuition and monthly stipend for duties performed, plus free health insurance and a cheap public transportation package through the UPass system. Researchers do not have to compete with their fellow colleagues. Instead, collaboration is encouraged.
cons: The University is highly selective even for some of the best applicants and hardest workers. It's all about who you know if you are accepted into a research position. Sometimes RAs are overworked and there can be a lack of communication, clear goals, and emotional support.

pros: Money. For a research institution not on one of the coasts NU pulls in huge amounts of money and spends it on fantastic facilities.
cons: It's surprisingly not all that collaborative of a place, from my experience. Researchers tend to stick to what they know and I have not witnessed all that much of people branching out of their comfort zones in order to do better research.

review_title: Highly ranked university. The working environment is perfect. The colleagues are very friendly. It is a beautiful campus
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Evanston, IL
pros: It is a small town it is very close to Chicago. People would love to work during the week and explore Chicago during weekend.
cons: Nothing is down side, really. It is among the best academia working enviroment in the USA. The students are the best. Would love to work here for a longer time.

pros: Good benefits-educational assistance, low-rate medical insurance, retirement plan, etc.
cons: Quite a few unprofessional and immoral faculty and administrators. Negative culture.

review_title: If I had it to do over again - I woudn't
pros:
My salary and until this year my career path were very positive.
The (external) reputation of the University is terrific.
cons:
Small changes in leadership equate to huge changes in the lower units.
NU is like any other corporation. It is driving by profit and expansion of it's business base. Failure to increase revenue/grow business is met with threats to your job.

pros: relaxed environment, nice people, meaningful job, chance to meet excellent mentors, also low housing price, big city life. I really enjoy working for my current employer. If it has higher salary, it would be even better. But anyway, life is more than money.
cons: low salary. That is the only thing I can think of. fifty thousand a year does not go long in Chicago. So I have to live in a small apartment and share a bathroom with a roommate. But the good thing is to have a good friend all the time.

review_title: Not the best place but not the worst
pros: benefits are  good to very good
cons:
lots of  red tape (bureaucracy!!) and internal issues leads to lots of turnover
Low or NO annual raise percentages due to university  budgeting mismanagement of the "higher ups."

pros: Great benefits, easy to get to if you live in the city, and the staff in the department are awesome people.
cons: Administrator overseeing the department has no idea what anyone does (regardless of the 25+ years employed here). Treats staff like chess pieces, invasive and bullying. This is not necessarily the case in all departments, which do vary in culteral climate. But working within the medical atmosphere is going to certainly yeild those with "holier-than-thou" complexes.

pros: Collaborative, civil, good benefits.  The staff are appreciated and included.  Salaries are nationally competitive.  The lakefront campus is beautiful, and there is a shuttle to downtown Chicago every 15 minutes.  The portable tuition benefits are amazing if your kids are college-age.
cons: I really cannot think of a negative -- it is the best place I have ever worked.  I have had no major issues or encountered a lot of red tape in my 8+ years here.  The parking ticketing office is unrelenting, though.

review_title: A good entry level position with great benefits and okay compensation in an engaged, if siloed community.
job_title: Program Assistant II in Evanston, IL
pros: Benefits, work environment, low-stress (sometimes).  Work is engaging and dynamic, but it often depends on your department.  The Silo nature of the university means that each department will have their own management style that makes it hard to insititute top-down changes.
cons: Promotions, slow to enact changes, staffing accountability.

pros: Lots of opportunities to work with interesting students and projects. Teaching Assistant for a multidisciplinary program. Teaching assistant job duties depend on who's leading the class.
cons: Students were confused with certain project deliverables that took time away from working on actual project goals (2 quarter class). Team Advisors were variable (some advisors were more available than others).

review_title: IT Consultant for Northwestern University Information Technology (NUIT)
pros: NUIT offers a competitive salary in comparison to other similarly available jobs on campus. The work environment is clean and professional. The office location is right on the border of campus and the city of Evanston, allowing easy access to great food during breaks.
cons: Current management is restrictive. Scheduling can be extremely bad but most co-workers are kind enough to trade hours with you when needed.

pros: tons of work-study jobs available for students and there are so many different areas of work that you are bound to be interested in one of them
cons: many times the pay is low or the job is very menial, but it's a job at least and if your work-study job is boring, then you can study in between breaks too.

review_title: Review of temp assignment at Northwestern University
pros: Laid back casual environment in a great location in Streeterville.  Generous benefits and tuition assistance when you are a permanent employee.
cons: Management had no idea what the employees were doing. Co-worker spent 8 hours a day on FaceBook and doing her homework.  No one seemed to care because she was cute and bubbly.  This had been going on for years.  When she was called on this by a co-worker, she got the woman fired.

pros: I work as a researcher under a professor. My boss gave me a lot of independence and he did not micromanage at all. Benefits are great: include medical, dental, and eye insurance at very affordable price. After one year of working, you can quality for retirement benefit where the university matches how much you put in. Maximum is 5% of your paycheck.
cons: It is very difficult to switch insurance at any time you want. There are only two periods when you can switch.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Evanston, IL
pros: Working at the Northwestern university was a great experience. It has a lovely campus, very  productive atmosphere, and what is important for research a good exposure to international research and conferences. For student, the university has a world class researches that know their subjects.
cons: As a research fellow, I am not really able to identify cons. Perhaps, within science faculty, there are too many talks, but I would still consider it to be pros than cons. However, it will require a better time management from the researcher.

review_title: Worked as an Instructor, Teaching Assistant, Research Assistant, Graduate Assistant, and Tutor
pros: Great access to digital and print resources (world-class library and subscriptions to many expensive research databases).
cons: The Graduate School was not very supportive of graduate students, denying them university funding opportunities after their fifth year when the average time to complete a Ph.D. is much longer than five years. Also, the university-sponsored health insurance for graduate student employees was mediocre.

pros: flexible work schedule, beautiful campus next to the lake, affordable housing options nearby, accessible by public transport and intercampus shuttle buses available.
cons:
low salary, stress level largely depends on adviser with high intensity periods leading up to a publication. TA positions when no external funding is available can be very time consuming.

Hardly got to know anyone from other departments/groups other than my own.
